dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Appian Road is empty at this time of a day. There is only long shadow of PETER THE APOSTLE, who looks ahead at the hilly surrounding area. Beneath his hood you can see his grave expression and tired face. The sun begins to appear from over the hillsides. Peter shields his eyes with his hand, trying to see the white pigeon, which flapped its wings loudly. Peter sinks to his knees, resting his hands and head on h staff. Around his outline appears a pulsing, golden light Than the single beam of light splits like a prism into tw streaks - one of them is pale pink - another clear luminous. The staff slides from under him and he falls face down i the Sand, his head still covered by his hood. Peter stretches his hands forward as if reaching for someoneвЂ™ feet. Silence falls. The golden light fades. Peter raises his h slightly.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Quo Vadis, Domine?

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 7 DAY_INT_PETRONIUS PALACE_ATRIUM
dialogues.text: The interior of PETRONIUSвЂ™S home. Petronius stands in his atrium close to a pool filled wit fresh water. There is a statue of Petronius behind him. B he and his statue stand motionless. Petronius observes th golden haired EUNICE, who is straightening the folds in h tunic. MARK VINICIUS enters the atrium with the springy step of soldier.

dialogues.speaker: VINCICIUS
dialogues.text: Greetings Petronius! May the Gods bring you prosperity!

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: By Jupiter! My nephew Marcus Vinicius! A true god of war. Dear me, let me embrace you! Petronius makes a sudden movement towards Marcus Vinicius unknowingly almost knocking Eunice over. Petronius hugs Vinicius.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Welcome back to Rome! You return from the war in Armenia? Vinicius takes a step back and turns sideways to Petroniu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes and a sorry business it is, a totally unnecessary war! He retreats further into the chamber. Petronius follows h and puts a hand on his shoulder. Vinicius turns his head.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: A true soldier turns away from war only when love has him enslaved. Do I guess correctly? Vinicius remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Has CupidвЂ™s arrow pierced your heart? Vinicius face glows with radiance.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: What a perceptive judge of people you are, Petronius! No wonder youвЂ™re CeaserвЂ™s chief counselor.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: To advise Nero, itвЂ™s sufficient to know the ways of monkeys. What am I saying! Even monkeys are not so stupid as to believe everything theyвЂ™re told.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Is it that bad at the Palatine? War lets you forget about those things.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: War even allows one to believe that thereвЂ™s a method to all this madness. But Rome will soon cure you of any such illusions. Unless, youвЂ™ve been enchanted by somemermaid. Speak up, boy! Vinicius grabs his arm and begins to speak rapidly.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Returning from the battle, I stopped at the house of Aulus Plautius. He made me most welcome, and that was where I saw her. One day, at dawn, I caught sight of her at the fountain. The morning rays (cD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: seemed to pass right through her body. ViniciusвЂ™ face beams. Petronius laughs.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: As transparent as a young sardine! So you truly have fallen in love with a mermaid!

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: FLASHBACK. Slow motion. LIGIA is seen from behind standin next to a fountain and dipping her hand in the cool water She turns to the camera and smiles with girlish innocence

dialogues.speaker: END OF SLOW MOTION
dialogues.text: Vinicius stands admiring Ligia. He is at first struck dum by her beauty.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Are you Venus?[Pause] Because only a goddess could look like that. Ligia stares at Vinicius, but makes no reply. A girlish smile full of curiosity spreads across her face.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Allow me Vinicius stutters like a nervous schoolboy.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS, (CD)
dialogues.text: .to... Ligia bends down and with her finger draws the "Pisces" symbol in the sand. Vinicius suddenly crouches beside her and when he tries to take her by the hand, but LigiaвЂ™s gives him the slip.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: They call her Lygia, but her name is Callina. She makes... this hunger burn inside me. She must be mine.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO REALITY
dialogues.text: Petronius watches with amusement as Vinicius nervously pa up and down the terrarium alongside the pool.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: The maiden or the fish?

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Both. In the meantime, several beautiful slave girls enter - tw Ethiopians, three slender Greeks and Eunice.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Better fish than these you see here are not to be found in all of Rome. Eunice! An intimidated Eunice walks up to them.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: What do you think of Eunice? She smells of violets. Even I do not know how sweet her kisses taste. Take her. Eunice throws herself at PetroniusвЂ™ feet, pleading.

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: Please, Master, donвЂ™t send me away. Petronius is visibly upset by her disobedience. Vinicius turns down the offer by shaking his head and turning his back to them as an Ethiopian slave presents a bowl of oils for Petronius to rinse his hands.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I want only Lygia. She is worth a hundred of these. She is the daughter of kings. Petronius wipes his brow, wraps his arm around ViniciusвЂ shoulder and leads him towards the exit.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: You mentioned hunger? LetвЂ™s go for breakfast. That will refresh the body, and then weвЂ™1ll do something for the soul. What do you think of (cD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the Plautiuses? What do you say we pay them a visit? After they exit, the slaves pick up all the baskets and bowls and leave. Eunice looks around and when she sees no one is looking s runs up to the statue of Petronius, stands on her toes an lightly kisses him on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 9 DAY_INT_PLAUTIUS PALACE_COLLONADE
dialogues.text: House of Aulus Plautius. Interior decorations in the atri leading to the garden. Petronius and Vinicius stand opposite their hosts, POMPON and AULUS PLAUTIUS. Beyond, in the courtyard, can be seen wonderful fountain. The pearls of water shine and reflect the sun with a rainbow. Petronius bows his head towards the hosts.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: I thank you for the hospitality you gave my sisterвЂ™s son.

dialogues.speaker: AULUS PLAUTIUS
dialogues.text: AS you well know, Petronius,I spent half my life on the battlefield. Seeing Marcus reminded me of my younger years. Today, as we grow older, our whole world lies within these walls.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: In my soul I think how different your world is from that over which our Nero reigns. Suddenly he turns his head at the sound of joyful laughte from a girl and child. Running up from the atrium is Lygia and little AULUS. The boy stumbles and falls at the feet of Petronius. Petronius and Lygia both lean down to pick up the child. Their eyes meet and lock momentarily. The little boy gets up on his own and runs out of the roo Lygia runs after him. Pomponia replies to Petronius with a wise, gentle smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s not Nero, but God who rules the world. Petronius turns towards Vinicius. Vinicius is standing as still as a statue, staring at the place where Lygia left room.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: There are many gods, everyone has his own. Pomponia responds with conviction.

dialogues.speaker: POMPONIA
dialogues.text: There is only one God - just and omnipotent

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Lightning. The contours of the street slowly emerge. Petronius and Vinicius are being carried in a litter. Beneath them the heads of noble pedestrians flash by. The litter, held up by runners, turns sharply through the crowd and its passengers almost fall out.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: And so you are writing poems? ThatвЂ™s quite the fashion these days. But you must be careful - Redbeard canвЂ™t abide competition. So youвЂ™d better be writing bad poems or none at all. Petronius smiles sadly. ViniciusвЂ™s expression does not change, then he suddenly explodes.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t care about Caesar, nor do I care about poetry! Petronius shakes his head impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: I do believe you really are in love.  Vinicius is uncomfortable in the litter. He bangs on the side and the runners come to a halt. Vinicius jumps out i the street among the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: And you, were you never in love? He yells at Petronius. Petronius gives him a manuscript a he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™s this?

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Poems. The author: Redbeard. Required reading. "Nero Augustus Ceasar" is written on the parchment. Vinicius shakes his head and moves away disappearing into the crowd. Petronius taps with his cane for the runners t continue.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: To the Palatine Hill, CeasarвЂ™s palace! The litter hastily moves away.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 11 DAY_INT_PLAUTIUS PALACE_ATRIUM
dialogues.text: The house of Aulus Plautius. The CENTURION HASTO enters w several PRAETORIAN GUARDS. The host stands in front of th group of soldiers. The centurion bows his head slightly.

dialogues.speaker: HASTO
dialogues.text: Commander! I bring you greetings from Caesar! Plautius frowns.

dialogues.speaker: AULUS PLAUTIUS
dialogues.text: Speak up Hasto! What is the charge? The centurion takes a step forward.

dialogues.speaker: HASTO
dialogues.text: No charges against you, sir, but an order from Caesar: the Divine Nero is grateful to you for giving shelter to the daughter of the barbarian king. But as a hostage, (cD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the girl belongs to Caesar. Therefore our divine emperor commands you to hand her over. Plautius turns around and looks at his wife, to whom Lygi is clinging. Next to the women stands the powerfully buil URSUS.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 12 DAY_INT_PLAUTIUS PALACE_ATRIUM
dialogues.text: Tears stream down the cheeks of Lygia and Pomponia. Plaut says with a voice that trembles.

dialogues.speaker: AULUS PLAUTIUS
dialogues.text: Lygia! Both Pomponia and I love you like a daughter, but you are CaesarвЂ™s responsibility ... Aulus walks past the women and disappears into the house. Ursus kneels before Pomponia.

dialogues.speaker: URSUS
dialogues.text: Domina! Allow me to go with my lady to the house of Caesar. She wipes away her tears.

dialogues.speaker: POMPONIA
dialogues.text: You are not mine, but LygiaвЂ™s servant, Ursus! Guard her closely! Little Aulus runs into the room and clings to LygiaвЂ™s l crying as Pomponia makes the sign of the cross on her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: POMPONIA
dialogues.text: May the Lord watch over you, daughter. Trust the God and believe that his mercy endures for ever.

dialogues.speaker: INT_PETRONIUS PALACE_PATIO
dialogues.text: Plautius steps out of his litter and heads into the home Petronius. On a shaded patio, Vinicius trains with his sword. He sto training at the sight of Plautius. Aulus Plautius and Vinicius stand opposite each other. Th commanderвЂ™s face is drawn in anger.  10.

dialogues.speaker: AULUS PLAUTIUS
dialogues.text: I curse the moment you and Petronius crossed the threshold of our house!

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Plautius! What are you saying? Why, I am the most faithful of all your friends!

dialogues.speaker: AULUS PLAUTIUS
dialogues.text: You are a thief! You have stolen my daughter! Vinicius rushes across to Plautius.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Speak up, tell me what has happened! Where is Lygia? Plautius halts Vinicius with a look, before he can get to worked up.

dialogues.speaker: AULUS PLAUTIUS
dialogues.text: Your uncle, Petronius persuaded Caesar to take Lygia to the Palatine, to his palace.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 14 NIGHT_EXT_ PALATINO_ PALACE ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: The grounds around CaesarвЂ™s palace - Palatine. Twilight growing buzz of laughter and cheers can be heard. The outlines of columns and rows of statues of gods can be se Along them move crowds of people heading towards CaesarвЂ feast. It gets darker; all that can be seen are the outlines of human figures moving in different directions. Somewhere f away music is playing. The light comes from lamps and lanterns, along with torches burning in the gardens. Two female figures are seen passing down a walkway border by perfectly trimmed hedges. They are illuminated by lamp burning on the ground behind them. The camera follows beh them, eventually catching up. One of the women is Lygia. She walks nervously, looking around anxiously. She is dressed in a beautiful gold tuni and a unique hair style. She seems a changed person as sh holds on tightly to the arm of the other woman, ACTE. Her companion is older but also beautiful and speaks with a warm, soothing voice.  11.

dialogues.speaker: ACTE
dialogues.text: You would incur the wrath of Caesar by not attending his banquet. He wants to see you! Fear not, Lygia. IвЂ™1l be right there with you.

dialogues.speaker: LYGIA
dialogues.text: You have been at NeroвЂ™s side... As a wife. But IвЂ™m so terribly afraid of him.

dialogues.speaker: ACTE
dialogues.text: That is why I promised Pomponia not to let you out of my sight. Calm yourself Lygia, Caesar will soon forget about you, and his Poppea will never allow him to come close to you! Lygia smileвЂ™s awkwardly as they disappear into the crow guests walking up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 15 NIGHT_EXT_ PALATINO_ PALACE ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Two male figures move along a walkway surrounded by illuminated sculptures. They enter into the circle of lig allowing them to be recognized. It is Petronius and Marcu Vinicius. MarcusвЂ™s face is clouded with emotion. Petronius repeat glances at his companion and says with sarcasm.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Cease this silence and grim expression, or they will think that you are hiding a dagger somewhere in the folds of your robes!

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: This is not what I wanted, Petronius! Petronius places his finger over his lips and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: You know too little of the ways of this world, Marcus. The war has made a savage of you. This is Rome. The centre of the world. Here we handle matters discretely.  12.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Lygia should not have been abducted from the house of the Plautiuses. Petronius responds strongly.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Only the emperor could have taken her away, to then give her to you. You will be able to spend this night in her arms. Vinicius is stopped in his tracks, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 16 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL
dialogues.text: Large hall. Palatine - CaesarвЂ™s Palace. A lot of guests tables in a brightly lit room. Candles flicker on the tab and walls but the guests at the tables sit gloomily in silence. Acte comes in with Lygia.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 17 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL
dialogues.text: The buzz and hum of the banquet. Servants bring in great plates of food. Acte and Lygia are seated behind the long table. Acte nods towards the brightly lit end of the room and it decorated table. Lygia looks towards the throne with disdain. At that moment the room erupts in great applause full of screaming and cheering.

dialogues.speaker: CROWDS
dialogues.text: Hail Caesar! Hail Caesar!Hail Caesar ! CEASAR NERO, surrounded by dignitaries, enters the room. Caesar is placed at the table next to his closest court, Among which are two arch-enemies fighting for influence i CaesarвЂ™s court - Petronius and TIGELLINUS - the command chief of the Praetorians. At that moment thousands of yellow rose petals fall from ceiling onto the tables and guests. Lygia stares at Nero. Lygia whispers with fascination.  13.

dialogues.speaker: LIGIA
dialogues.text: Redbeard...!

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 18 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL
dialogues.text: NeroвЂ™s table. Caesar looks around the room. After a mom he focuses and squints in one particular direction.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Is this the beauty that Vinicius loves so much? Tigellinus leans over to Caesar and whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: A beauty she is indeed Sire, too beautiful for Vinicius. PetroniusвЂ™s face contorts with anger.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Sire, you are more generous to Vinicius than if you were his own father. Even Tigellinus has noticed she is too narrow in the hips, but as usual he is trying to score. You have missed the boat, Tigellinus! Nero grabs his emerald monocle, puts it up to his eye and stares at Lygia. Both of them await NeroвЂ™s verdict. Ner busts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Yes, missed. Too narrow in the hips. Petronius releases a sigh of relief as Tigellinus sends h a deadly stare.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: Poppea! Poppea! Electrifying cheers run through the room. AUGUSTA POPPEA, the wife of Caesar approaches, majestical gliding across the hall dressed in robes the color of amethyst and wearing gorgeous jewelry and an amazing hairstyle resembling a giant sailing ship.  14. Nero, still staring at Lygia, pays no attention to his wi as he turns the emerald monocle around in front of his ey like a prism. Poppea walks up to Nero and snatches the monocle out of h hand. She stares into his face him and jealously hisses a him.

dialogues.speaker: POPPEA
dialogues.text: You donвЂ™t need this, my divine Nero. The greatest beauty is right beside you. Surprised, Nero turns to her with a grimace. He reaches o and tears a ruby from her neck and looks at her through i twirling the stone in front of his eye. POV Nero. This stone is cut with several facets; through we can see five heads of Poppea.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: This is a woman with five heads. IвЂ™1l get rid of at least four of them. Her hairdressers cost me too much. Poppea canвЂ™t hide the anger on her face but duly takes place next to her husband as thousands of red rose pedals fall from the ceiling. She mutters under her breath.

dialogues.speaker: POPPEA
dialogues.text: You better watch for your own head, Nero.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 20 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL
dialogues.text: Acte and Lygia at the table. Lygia watches Poppea with delight.

dialogues.speaker: LYGIA
dialogues.text: How beautiful she is!

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: You are a hundred times more beautiful. Lygia hears the voice of Vinicius, who is standing behind her.  15.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Hail, Callina-Lygia! Vinicius takes a place next to the girl, moving Acte to t side. He is wearing a scarlet tunic, his bare arms decora in golden epaulettes. Vinicius reluctantly looks at Acte. He grabs Lygia by her hand and leans over, whispering in her ear. Lygia tries t pull away gently.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I knew IвЂ™d find you here. But little did I know it would make me so happy! Acte begins to intervene as Vinicius pulls Lygia towards him, but upon hearing Nero is going to sing, she interrup wanting everyone to listen to him sing.

dialogues.speaker: ACTE
dialogues.text: Hold your breaths! Caesar is about to sing.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 21 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL
dialogues.text: Nero recites a poem, posing grotesquely like an actor, wh holding his zither in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: NERON
dialogues.text: Sweet Venus, founder of Rome and pride of the Gods, You who guard travelers on the high seas, and make the land fruitfull for all living things, the Goddess of sunlight who stills the storm for you clouds clear away... The young FREEDMAN PITAGORAS kneels at the feet of Caesar He removes the laurel wreath from his head and puts it at the feet of Caesar with an expression of adulation on his face.

dialogues.speaker: CROWDLL
dialogues.text: Oh heavenly voice! Our divine Caesar! Redbeard, the greatest poet in the world! Nero looks quizzically at Petronius and then at Tigellinu then again at Petronius. A boundless self-admiration appe on his face.  16. Petronius remains in an indifferent silence, as if the spectacle did not make the slightest impression on him. Not finding delight in the eyes of Petronius, Nero change his expression to that of a little boy begging for the praise of his father. Petronius drags out the situation b in the end speaks while retaining his stone face.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Cursed be the fate that has us live with such a poet. Were his verses any worst, perhaps I could find it in my heart to praise them. But I remain silent. Embarrassed. Destroyed by their beauty. NeroвЂ™s face lights up with delight and boundless vanity Nero grabs a chalice to take a drink of wine. Pitagoras throws himself to pour more wine for Nero as Tigellinus fumes in jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: Thy verses, Caesar, were born like you among the gods. Their father is Zeus Apollo and their mother.... Nero turns red in anger.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Silence Fool! My mother was Agrippina, a cursed woman... A gloomy expression appears on NeroвЂ™s face.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: I had no choice; I had to sentence her to death, because she sent an assassin to murder me. If I hadnвЂ™t acted quicker than her, you would not have heard me singing today. Tigellinus, wanting to calm CaesarвЂ™s anger, yells out w excitement in his face as he raises a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: On behalf of the city and the world I thank you Caesar for destroying your mother and freeing us from her evil power.  17. With contempt Petronius stares at Tigellinus and reaches NeroвЂ™s emerald monocle, putting it up to his eye. Throu he sees the weird party and its already drunk guests, hugging, kissing, raising glasses and eating. In the background, shadowy slaves move around carrying massive trays of food and pitchers of wine. The image is drowned by another precipitation of multicolored rose petals. Petronius removes the sapphire from his eye and hands it to Nero, jolting him from his m distant stare.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Close your ears, Nero, lest the words of fools hurt them. Your world is like an emerald. Rare and fragile.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 22 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL
dialogues.text: An already drunk Vinicius wraps his arms around Lygia. Sh tries to get out of his grasp.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Lygia, Lygia...! Kiss me! Caesar has promised you to me...!

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 23 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL
dialogues.text: Loud noises as Gladiators enter the arena between the tables. With bare bodies rubbed in oil, they begin to battle. Two guests shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST GUEST
dialogues.text: I wager that Croto will wring his neck! The fight continues. One of the gladiators wins an advantage, choking his opponent and throwing him to the ground. The winner puts a foot on the back of his foe and crosses his arms over his chest in a sign of victory. The hall erupts in the cheers of the men and women looking on.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Croto! Croto! Croto!  18.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 24 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL
dialogues.text: Vinicius tries to kiss Lygia, in the struggle she knocks over a cup of wine. HeвЂ™s drunk, with no control over himself. He mumbles, meanwhile Acte tries to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: [Drunk] Love me, Lygia! It was I that beat the Parthians and bore the glory of Rome to the world. And now Rome gives me my due reward worthy of a hero. You!...(his speech slurs off into drunken mumbling) Lygia tries to push him away with her last ounce of strength. Acte tries to restrain him. At this moment a gigantic form appears above Vinicius. A giant - Ursus appears from behind Vinicius and picks Ly up like a doll. They disappear among the guests and servants, meanwhile Vinicius is too drunk to realize what happening.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 25 DAY_INT_PETRONIUS PALACE_ATRIUM
dialogues.text: House of Petronius. Atrium. Petronius is walking alongsid the pool, scolding Vinicius, who is hiding his face in hi hands.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: It is as I feared. This war has made a savage of you. You have become one of us. A bastard of the court. Redbeard can be proud of you. I have forfeited the friendship of the Plautiuses just to decorate your empty head with a wreath of withered leaves. Vinicius drops his head in shame. Petronius is furious. Eunice silently slips into the room and turns towards Petronius.

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: Master, I found the man that youвЂ™re looking for and who is looking for you. From behind Eunice appears a clumsy figure of an old man a torn coat, who bows and mutters. CHILON CHILONIDES.  19.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Chilon Chilonides at the service of the equal and the more equal. Petronius looks the man over with interest and then stare at Eunice. He regards her with amusement. Eunice blushes walks out in embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 26 DAY_INT_PETRONIUS PALACE_ATRIUM
dialogues.text: Chilon smiles at Eunice as she runs out.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: She complains of unrequited love. I gave her two threads from the mantle of Venus. I have my methods.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Are you a magician? The stranger pulls his clumsy hands from his worn coat. H smile contorts his face.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: A philosopher, Master! Do you not know? Vinicius stands over Chilo.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Do You know what we want from you? Chilon squints his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: I am to find some girl who has been abducted by her slave from a feast held by Caesar. Vinicius yells back in anger.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Only remember, this is not just some girl, you villain. It is the divine daughter of the King of the Lygians, called Callina! Chilon stares into PetroniusвЂ™s face, unsure who is in c and who holds the money. He is afraid of Vinicius. Petronius calms the situation.  20.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Do you have a way to do this?

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: If you have the means, sir, IвЂ™1l1 find a way.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: So you are a philosopher for money, in other words a crook. Petronius seems cynical, as the newcomer once again fiddl with his old coat.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m saving up, to hire a scribe, whoвЂ™1l transmit my message to posterity. For myself, I do not keep a penny. Not even for a coat. From one side, Vinicius throws Chilon a bag jingling with coins. Even though he wasnвЂ™t looking, he catches it lik juggler.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: When will you start? Chilon hides the bag in his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: I already have! His tone becomes confident.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Noble lords, will you permit me to in turn ask a question or two? Petronius nods.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Did you notice the divine Lygia having any special marks: amulets, tattoos? Vinicius shakes his head. Chilon falls back and frowns.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: It wonвЂ™t be easy. Vinicius comes to life and suddenly shouts.  21.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: But wait! I remember now! She drew a fish in the sand! Chilo twists his head and mutters.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: A Fish?

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: A Fish.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: I shall do all in my power... but....you see for yourselves... you understand... Showing the holes in his coat as he slowly walks backward towards the exit and disappears. Petronius calls out to h

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Tell my servant to give you a new coat! From outside the door Chilo calls back.

dialogues.speaker: CHILO, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Thou art a true philosopher, Master! You hate even the slightest injustice. Eunice shows up in the doorway looking more beautiful tha usual. Petronius looks at her in amazement. Vinicius interrupts his staring.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: What now? Petronius puts his fingers to his nose and, changing his voice, pretends to be Chilon.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: First we fumigate the house, and then ask Eunice to accompany us. Eunice runs up to Petronius. He caresses the flowers in h hair and asks haughtily.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Could it be that love really exists? Happy is he who experiences it.  22.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 27 EVENING_EXT_ DARK ROME STREET
dialogues.text: Darkness. A gloomy path on which Chilon is sneaking benea gray walls. He runs into the first lit building, a winery

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 28 EVENING_INT_ WINERY
dialogues.text: The interior of the winery. Chilon sits down at the neare table.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Wine, Sporus! The host puts a pitcher before him. The Greek pushes it away.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Something better than this, you swindler! The best in the house! He shouts out and throws a gold coin on the table. Sporus hands him a chalice. Chilon takes a huge gulp and pours t last bit onto the table top. He draws the shape of a fish in the wine. Sporus watches with a blunt expression.

dialogues.speaker: CHILO
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen this sign? SporusвЂ™ face expressionless. A second gold coin falls o the table.

dialogues.speaker: SPORUS
dialogues.text: All types frequent this place.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Do you know who these are? Sporus mumbles.

dialogues.speaker: SPORUS
dialogues.text: Fish...people? A third gold coin falls on the table.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Can you at least count to three, fool? SporusвЂ™ eyes light up. He grabs the coins and wipes awa drawing in the wine.  23.

dialogues.speaker: SPORUS
dialogues.text: Fish in Greek is Ichthys. Jesus Christ, the Son of God, the Saviour.

dialogues.speaker: CHILO
dialogues.text: Christ? The one who was crucified in Judea?

dialogues.speaker: SPORUS
dialogues.text: The same.

dialogues.speaker: WITH A TABLE
dialogues.text: A golden sunset, though the sky is still blue. Chilon sne up to the home of Crispus and cautiously looks inside. At a table are sat: the Apostles Peter and Paul, Crispus, Nazarius and Lygia. Peter breaks bread, dips a piece in w and passes it to Paul. He passes out the bread, doing the same for all those present. This scene is accompanied by music.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 29 DAY_INT_PETRONIUS PALACE_ATRIUM
dialogues.text: House of Petronius. In the doorway appears the haggard figure of Chilon.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Pax Vobiscum. Peace be with you. Vinicius grabs him, pulls him in and shakes him like a do

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Where have you been, you villain!? He yells through clenched teeth. ChilonвЂ™s voice breaks as he wheezes.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t choke me, Sir. IвЂ™m just a philosopher. Chilon wheezes and snorts trying to catch his breath.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Where is Lygia?  24.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: SheвЂ™s safe, among her own people.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Your divine Lygia is a non-divine Christian. Vinicius is stopped in his tracks, but after a while, una to find an answer to this news, he turns to Chilon in a m friendly tone.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Do you now anything more?

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: More means more....for the both of us, less than tomorrow, but a lot more than yesterday. Chilon is alluding to extra payment.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: HavenвЂ™t I paid you enough?

dialogues.speaker: CHILO
dialogues.text: HavenвЂ™t I told you enough, Sir? Chilon immediately responds. Vinicius opens a box and pul out another purse with money for Chilon.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Here, take this, and youвЂ™1ll get a lot more when you lead me to her.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 30 NIGHT_EXT_DARK ROME SUBURBAN STREETS
dialogues.text: Darkness. Two hooded characters move through narrow alleyways. Behind them follows a hooded figure, the enorm and powerfully built Croto. The shortest of the three removes his hood, showing the face of Chilon.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Who is this, Sir? Chilon nods towards the second figure who takes his hood off.  25.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Croto. The Wrestler.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: You are a cautious man, Sir. Guarding your virgin is a true giant. Vinicius shoves Chilon, whose hood falls over his face.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: If you have lied to me, Croto will count your bones first and then he will deal with the giant!

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: But if IвЂ™m telling the truth?

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: You will receive a house and five slaves.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: This very night, Christians will be gathering in Ostrianum. There is to be a man present who knew Christ. They call him "The Rock" - Petrus. The Apostle Peter. They are going to pray together. ThatвЂ™s where weвЂ™ll find her, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 31 NIGHT_EXT_RAVINE OUTSIDE ROME
dialogues.text: The three hooded figures are close to the entrance to a d ravine. Around them, ahead, on all sides and at the top o the ravine are hundreds of twinkling lights. The lights a concentrated in one meandering stream flowing down to the bottom of the ravine. Vinicius, Chilon and Croto, still hidden beneath their hoods, slow their pace, allowing others to hurry past the on their way up to the outlet of the ravine.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 32 NIGHT_INT_CAVE IN OSTRIANUM
dialogues.text: One of the caves in Ostrianum. Two fires burn by a wall t has windows giving a view over distant houses scattered along via Nomentana.  26. Lights go out in the houses as the residents go to sleep. Someone lights a bonfire with a torch, lighting up the ar then follows an interval filled with light and song. The shadows of those in attendance reflect off the side of th ravine. The cameraвЂ™s view is from behind Vinicius and Chilon. T men stand far back from the fires. By the fire stands the old Apostle Peter. He stands tall straight with dignity and inner strength. The light from fire illuminates his gray head and aged face. He speaks. Around him the hooded figures listen.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s the one, the first disciple of Christ, a fisherman! Peter raises his hand, making the sign of the cross, blessing the followers, who fall to their knees.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I have come to greet you in the name of He who sent me. I have come to tell you to renounce luxuries and pleasures. To love poverty, moral purity and truth. To endure patiently all harm and persecution, to beware of treachery, and set an example for one another. In ViniciusвЂ™s eyes we see the reflection of the fires. the influence of PeterвЂ™s words his face begins to chang the fire reflecting off of his eyes the gentle face of Ly appears.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I saw Him, and he was like light and the joy of our hearts, for we believed that He rose again and though the seas may dry up, and the mountains turn to dust, His glory shall not pass... Chilon tugs at ViniciusвЂ™s coat.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: There! Take a look! HeвЂ™s right there! The giant! Vinicius turns his head in the direction of ChilonвЂ™s pointing finger. He sees the massive Ursus.  27.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 33 NIGHT_INT_CAVE IN OSTRIANUM
dialogues.text: At that moment, the followers begin to sing as they move forward to Peter and bow their heads. Peter dips a branch in water and baptizes them. Lygia stands next to Ursus, staring off in front of her a the dancing flames reflect off their faces, making her almost transparent. Vinicius takes off his hood.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Lygia! Vinicius rushes forward but Chilon holds him back, grabbi him by the coat.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Wait, Sire! YouвЂ™1ll bring disaster on our heads. When this is all over, weвЂ™ll follow them, and then, in the darkness, this fellow here... Chilon looks at Croto, who is standing behind them with h arms crossed over his chest. He makes a gesture with his hands as if breaking UrsusвЂ™s bones. He takes one step forward and directs his mindless, but faithful gaze on Vinicius.

dialogues.speaker: CROTO
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 34 NIGHT_EXT_RAVINE OUTSIDE ROME
dialogues.text: High on the tops of the ravine we can see the silhouettes those returning home from the Christian meeting. The sky the background is slowly lightening as dawn approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 35 NIGHT_EXT_ ROME STREET
dialogues.text: A dark alley. Chilon looks around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: They went into that house. He whispers, nodding towards the gray facade of a house. Croto stands in front of the building opposite the entran  28.

dialogues.speaker: CROTO
dialogues.text: Now? From behind him appears the shorter Vinicius.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Now! He cries out his decision and leads the way. Then they disappear into the hallway leading into the house, while Chilon hides behind the corner.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT_EXT_CRISPUS HOUSE COURTYARD 1
dialogues.text: They walk down a long hallway. A large figure appears and blocks their progress. From the darkness emerges the face Ursus.

dialogues.speaker: URSUS
dialogues.text: And who would you be seeking?

dialogues.speaker: CROTO
dialogues.text: You! Croto screams and throws himself on the giant.

dialogues.speaker: CROTO
dialogues.text: RAAAAAARUH! [Savage battle cry]

dialogues.speaker: URSUS
dialogues.text: UNNH! [Grunts in reaction] The two giants fight.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 37 NIGHT_EXT_CRISPUS HOUSE_COURTYARD 2
dialogues.text: Vinicius runs down the hallway and out into a courtyard. By a fireplace burning in the courtyard Lygia sits, accompanied by an old man, CRISPUS. Vinicius heads towards them. The fire illuminates the fac of Lygia and Crispus. Vinicius pushes the old man out of the way and grabs the girl. He runs back out of the courtyard. In his way lies fallen body of Croto. Ursus inflicts a heavy blow to ViniciusвЂ™s head. The fre Lygia calls out to the giant.  29.

dialogues.speaker: LIGIA
dialogues.text: No, Ursus!!! No! DonвЂ™t kill him! Vinicius slumps to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 38 DAY_INT_CRISPUS HOUSE_MAIN CHAMBER
dialogues.text: Darkness. Voices can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: VINICUS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Kill me. His voice is full of sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CRISPUS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: He was lucky; you almost broke his neck, Ursus.

dialogues.speaker: URSUS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: In my former life I killed a lot of people, but back then I did not know Christ.

dialogues.speaker: LIGIA, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Trust in the Lord, Ursus. He knows best why you were born with such strength. And such a great heart...

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 39 DAY_INT_CRISPUS HOUSE_MAIN CHAMBER
dialogues.text: House of Crispus. Vinicius is lying on a bed with a serio head wound. He opens his eyes. Crispus leans over the injured Vinicius and wipes his forehead with a damp cloth. Ursus looks at him from a distance as Crispus treats him. In the corner, there is Nazarius sitting on a low stool. He is cutting a piece of wood to a form of a little bird. Lygia sits at the end of the bed. When Vinicius sees her he whispers with all his strength.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s you, Lygia. Lygia looks at him with care.  30.

dialogues.speaker: LYGIA
dialogues.text: Peace be with you, Marcus. Crispus hands Vinicius a clean slate with a stylus.

dialogues.speaker: CRISPUS
dialogues.text: God tells us to love our enemy, so we have dressed your wounds. Now write a note to your people, have them come for you. Vinicius tries to lift his head.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: You want me to leave? Now, when IвЂ™ve found Lygia!? I have harmed her, itвЂ™s true. But I swear to the gods, to my gods, that I will not touch the woman I love more than my life. May your God also be my witness. Permit me to stay. If only for one day. ViniciusвЂ™ head falls back. Lygia, emotionally moved by his words, rises from the end the bed with her eyes turned to Crispus.

dialogues.speaker: LIGIA
dialogues.text: Let him stay. Let him live.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 40 DAY_EXT_LAKE WITH A BOAT
dialogues.text: Dream of Vinicius and his POV. Water floods his vision. One can see how he is struggling with the waves. Around him is darkness, wind, a storm. He struggling, losing strength until he slides under the wat With his last ounce of strength, he pulls himself to the surface and reaches out to grab the end of an oar, by mea of which he is hauled into a boat. It turns out the perso who handed him the oar is Peter. The fishing boat is going across a wide fiery lake. A swe angelic hymn begins to play as the boat reaches a shore w clean golden sand. The white pigeon is silently gliding at the sky. End of P Vinicius wet and tired after battling the elements lies o his back in the boat.  31. Peter is not there anymore, as Lygia bends over Vinicius with a gentle, beautiful smile.

dialogues.speaker: LYGIA
dialogues.text: Come, follow me; IвЂ™11 show you the way!

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Vinicius opens his eyes in the house of Crispus. His head rests on the lap of Lygia, who is stroking his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I saw your soul in a dream.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 42 DAY_INT_CRISPUS HOUSE_MAIN CHAMBER
dialogues.text: Lygia melts away like a ghost. It was a ghost, a dream. ViniciusвЂ™s head still rests motionless, but now itвЂ™s on a cushion instead of LygiaвЂ™s lap.

dialogues.speaker: URSUS
dialogues.text: Lygia told me you should drink this, Master. Ursus comes closer to Vinicius and hands him a metal cup with some hot brew, the cup hidden in his massive hands.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Are you LygiaвЂ™s slave?

dialogues.speaker: URSUS
dialogues.text: Where we come from, there are no slaves.

dialogues.speaker: VINCIUS
dialogues.text: Where is that?

dialogues.speaker: URSUS
dialogues.text: Where the forest has no end, where there are castles made of wood, and a great abundance of honey and bread. Where "yes" means "yes" and "no" means "no"  32.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: And Lygia?

dialogues.speaker: URSUS
dialogues.text: When you Romans appeared in our forests, LygiaвЂ™s father, our king died from a Roman arrow. Soon after that her mother died. Your leader Plautius took the child under his wing. Rome became her home. And Christ her consolation. There is a transition to a stable from this chamber. You see a donkey, which is eating hay in a shadow and suddenl a face of Lygia, hidden there, listening, close to the donkey - appears.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Christ! who is he, that he could bring consolation to the Romans!?

dialogues.speaker: URSUS
dialogues.text: He who changes sorrow to joy. And death itself, which for you is the end of life, is for us the beginning. Lygia runs out of her hiding and faces Vinicius.

dialogues.speaker: LYGIA
dialogues.text: Yes! Believing in Christ we cannot be unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: And I am happy believing in you. I donвЂ™t need Christ for that.

dialogues.speaker: LYGIA
dialogues.text: You are mistaken, Marcus. Christ is love.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: If it is as you say, let me see for myself. Be my wife. We will celebrate the biggest wedding ever seen in Rome. I shall ask the emperor himself for his blessing... Lygia looks at Vinicius. Her eyes begin to fill with tears and she runs out of the room.  33.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 43 DAY_EXT_CRISPUS HOUSE_COURTYARD 2
dialogues.text: Upset, Lygia runs out of the room and into the courtyard where fish are hung up and drying. Peter is sitting on a bench, leaning against his staff. N to him sits the taller and more powerfully built APOSTLE PAUL. NAZARIUS(16), PeterвЂ™s compagnion is sitting under the t HE stays silent, but his nimble finger turn a piece of wo and a knife. Now you can see a bird figurine that Nazariu sculpts. Running through the courtyard, she doesnвЂ™t notice them Paul speaks.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: God bless you, my child. Lygia stops and turns around to look at them. Peter taps his staff on the flagstones beneath his feet. Lygia lowers her head and approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sit down with us, young lady. Lygia sits down on the stones beside the bench and begins listen to their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you remember how you attended the wedding at Canaa in Galilee? Peter nods his head with a smile, remembering the old tim

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: But you werвЂ™nt there! How do you know about that?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You told me all about it yourself, remember?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: My mind is weakened by old age, but John has written everything down. Have you read it?  34.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, IвЂ™ve read the whole thing. You went to a wedding, and they ran out of wine.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And Jesus called a servant and said, "Fill the wine jars with water."

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He blessed the love between the woman and the man. The apostles now look at Lygia sitting by their feet listening to the conversation. She begins to blush, but sits in silence with no need to speak, just to listen.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: While the eyes of the one you love remain closed to the light of truth, avoid him so that he does not lead you into sin. But pray for him and know that thereвЂ™s no sin in your love. Paul glances at Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Trust in your love. Christ has softened hearts even harder than the heart of one Roman. Peter nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thrice I denied our Lord, but he forgave me and commanded me to be a good shepherd to the people. Apostle Paul stands up, turning out to be a large man.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 44 NIGHT_INT_PETRONIUS PALACE_LIBRARY
dialogues.text: House of Petronius. He lounges in a seat in his library. The soft light of the moon enters to the library. Eunice peeks around the corner, looks at Petrnonius as always, with love, as he quietly reads verses of Horace o loud.  35.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: I will not all die, a greater part of me will rise again. As long as high priest climbes the Capitoline Hill... Petronius raises his eyes from the pages and continues to speak the verse in near silence. Petronius can see Eunice looking at him, unaware that she reflected in a huge mirror. He momentarily stops reciting and then suddenly ends the poem aloud, as if speaking to Eunice.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: ...May Melpomene, the muse of song take pride in what I have made of all talents she gave to me, and crown my head with laurel wreath. Without taking his eyes off Eunice, he puts down the book

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Have you ever thought about freedom, Eunice? Eunice retreats behind her corner, hiding.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: You could leave this place, if I were to free you. Eunice suddenly appears from around the corner again.

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: Oh no! Please donвЂ™t do any such thing, Master. Eunice approaches him from behind as he continues to look her in the large brass mirror.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Freed, you could go your own way, have a husband, children, a life of your own... Eunice falls to her knees.

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: You are my life, my Lord.  36.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: But admit that you envy the beautiful Romans, their fine apparel, jewellery, hairstyles, lovers...

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: Love is not jealous or boastful, is not borne up by pride. Eunice looks into his eyes and then he sees what kind of innocent soul hides behind her beautiful face. He reaches out towards her with his hand but doesnвЂ™t touch her, as he were scared to touch such beauty. He motions to her to come closer.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: But what if I sent you to work in the fields? What if I married another woman? Or had you whipped?

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: Love bears every kind of suffering, believes all things, sees hope everywhere, endures everything.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: But sooner or later it ends, burns out and dies... Petronius slides out of his seat and reaches out towards Eunice without touching her, kneeling in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: Love never dies.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 45 DAY_INT_PETRONIUS PALACE_ATRIUM
dialogues.text: Vinicius reclines by the pool in PetroniusвЂ™ home. He still has a bandage on his head. Petronius is sitting across the pool with Eunice on his l He says irritably.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: And so you have gone quite mad. You free your slaves, distribute your fortune among the poor  37.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I have come to believe their teaching that happiness, beauty, and love are nothing but vanity.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: If you want to repay evil with goodness ... then ... then what do you repay goodness with!? Vinicius raises his hand and interrupts Petronius. Petron begins to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I cannot repay their goodness with evil. Petronius angrily turns around.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Do you intend to accept the teachings of this ... Christ?!

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: When IвЂ™m ready.... I would like you to meet him too, Petronius. At that moment a beautiful Greek slave enters the room an hands Petronius a letter, he reads it and with a sigh thr the paper into the pool like a paper boat.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Caesar orders us to go together to Antium. I advise you not to refuse such a request.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I cannot leave Lygia.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: If you do not wish to lose her for ever, better start packing before Redbeard notices your absence

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I want nothing from Caesar. If IвЂ™m going anywhere, then I shall go with Lygia and the Plutiuses to Sicily. If that is what she wants... Petronius looks at Vinicius with growing pity.  38.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: No one is free. Everyone has someone above him who decides whether he lives or dies. Keep that rule in mind. ChilonвЂ™s contorted face appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Psst....

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: What is he doing here?! Chilon approaches them and reaching the pool, sits down, takes off his sandals, and dips his tired feet in the col water. He begins his game with a mysterious expression.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: I know where to find.... Vinicius jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: You dare not speak her name! Chilon is completely surprised by this turn of events.

dialogues.speaker: CHILO
dialogues.text: Why is that, sir? What has changed since you promised me a house and five slaves. Have I not kept my word? Vinicius grabs Chilon by his coat and lifts him up over t pool, his feet dangling above the water.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m telling you not to hang around here any more and to forget that you ever knew us.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: If you drown old Chilo, youвЂ™1l be doing a favour to the enemies of Rome. Along with me will perish matters important to the Empire, saved in this head of mine. Chilon tries to tap his head. Vinicius eventually throws down at the edge of the pool.  39.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: You are to cease your spying, now! And do not show up around! Vinicius throws a purse of coins towards the door. Chilon runs after it and catches it, already close to the exit. He turns around and looks at Vinicius with plots an revenge in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: YouвЂ™re very generous, Sir. Chilo will never forget it. He gives a low bow an exits.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 46-47 EVENING_ANTIUM AT THE SEA SIDE_EXT_TERRACE
dialogues.text: Antium. A large terraced villa. Below can be seen the cal waters of the bay.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: And so Troy burns, burns, burns... Nero, with a zither in his hands plays the last two chord pathetically picking at the strings as he leans against a rail under a blood red sunset. The groan of the zither endlessly prolongs the last notes NeroвЂ™s poem. He looks around at Petronius, Vinicius, Poppea and Tigellinus with an expression of boundless pride. Tigellinus claps his hands with an idiotic smile as he no his head, as if he was agreeing with what he had just hea

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: What do you say? Did you see the fire that consumes Troy? Tigellinus, you first - what do you think of my description. Nero is surrounded by Petronius, Vinicius, Poppea and Tigellinus. Servants move around silently in the backgrou Nero has just finished reading a poem, now he proudly coc his head and looks at those present. Tigellinus claps his hands in appreciation and nods.  40.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: Amazing!

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Amazing? Tigellinus! But was it true? Did you feel the fire burn your hands?! Tigellinus stutters like a pupil in front of the blackboa

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: Oh! Divine one! It burned and... blinded! Nero casts Petronius a contemptuous look. Moving across, he closely observes Poppea, who with a loo of indifference on her face, stuffs some grapes into her mouth. She has no understanding or interest in the poetry Caesar. With a look of disgust, Nero turns around and yells out t the servants with an impatient voice.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Clear the tables. Augusta is choking. Two servants instantly bring out trays and bowls. Meanwhile, Nero looks at Petronius intensely. Petronius withstands the long stare, and after a long pau pronounces his judgment.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Throw your verse in the fire, Caesar; that would be the best thing for it. Caesar tries to control his anger and squints at him.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: What do you find so wrong in my description of the fire, Petronius, that you would have the fire consume it?

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: It is too cold.  41.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: It burnt Tigellinus.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t believe him, divine Caesar. Your talent could wipe Rome from the surface of the earth, let alone Troy! Hearing this, Nero calms down.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s true. The gods gave me talent. That is why I am sharing it with you.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: The greatest poet of Rome does not look for acclaim from his soldiers, but is worthy of eternal glory in the pantheon of fame. Nero swells with pride and looks at Tigellinus with contempt, who shrinks in his armor.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Tigellinus has the mind of a mouse and skin thin as a womanвЂ™s. Come back tomorrow, Petronius, and you will die in the flames. TigellinusвЂ™s face blackens with anger.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: As a sculptor seeks his model, so I need to see a real fire.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: At your command, Sire, I will order all of Antium to be set alight for you!

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: What is Antium for Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 48 NIGHT_EXT_ANTIUM AT THE SEA SIDE_BEACH
dialogues.text: Antium. Coast. Petronius and Vinicius walk slowly along a sandy beach. Jupiter shines like a lantern.  42.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: ArenвЂ™t you playing with life and death? Wrapped in his thoughts, Petronius for a moment doesnвЂ™t reply.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: If you want Caesar to agree to your wedding with Lygia, he must be pleased with himself.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: So why do you tease Tigellinus?

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Tigellinus does all he can to prejudice Caesar against me. Small waves lap the shore.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: It is said he who lives by the sword, dies by the sword.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: It is also said: if you want peace - prepare for war.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: How are we to know what itвЂ™s all worth. IвЂ™m a soldier and you area diplomat ... who will judge us?

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: You yourself and I myself. The late evening horizon is illuminated by the sphere of Jupiter, lighting up the way for the two men walking acro the beach as tiny waves crash onto the shore.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 49 EVENING_ANTIUM AT THE SEA SIDE_EXT_TERRACE
dialogues.text: Small waves lap the sands. The crackling and popping of burning wood and houses. The great fire, born in NeroвЂ™s head, in his poem, reflects of the water. The flames were born in NeroвЂ™s head, in N poem. We can heard only the groan of his zithar.  43. Nero is watching from the terrace of a villa in Antium. H turns around and looks at the room of guests, as if waiti for applause. Petronius speaks first.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: We need air, Caesar. We are suffocating and the fires of Troy will soon reach us.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: What are you saying, Petronius? Have the stanzas of my poem made such an impression on you?

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: I am quite burning up and donвЂ™t know what will quench the fire. You have ruined my life, Sire. Vinicius, who remains stubbornly silent, could say the same, if he were not frozen with terror.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: What have you to say about my fire - youвЂ™ve felt the fire of battle? Vinicius freezes, not knowing what to say in response to Nero. Tigellinus takes advantage.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: Divine Caesar. Though I have been in a hundred battles... Nero, with a gesture signals him to be silent. He looks a Vinicius, expecting an answer. Petronius tries to help.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Vinicius would rather die than face the might of your poems, Nero. Nero breaks out into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Then you shall die, Vinicius, if you donвЂ™t tell me whether youвЂ™d prefer to receive a poem or a horse from me? Petronius is bitterly silenced.  44.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: IвЂ™d rather have a poem, Sire.Horses there are many, but only one Caesar. Nothing is worth more than his words. NeroвЂ™s face lights up in appreciation and he cries out the servants from the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Bring me my horse! He turns to Petronius.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: They think me a monster ... they call me matricidal, they are jealous of my talent. The burden of Magnitude is hard to bear. You alone understand me - the Artist! He puts his hand on PetroniusвЂ™s shoulder. Tigellinus as always looks on their relationship with jealousy. The servants bring along his horse beneath the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: And I do so like to make people happy. Vinicius - the steed is yours! Confused, Vinicius looks at Petronius. Petronius nods reassuringly, implying that you canвЂ™t refuse Nero. Footsteps on the terrace approach from behind. Nero turns around. Faon, the freedman falls to his knees in front of Nero.

dialogues.speaker: FAON
dialogues.text: Forgive me, divine emperor! There is a fire in Rome! The greater part of the town on fire! Nero looks at him with curiosity then raises his eyes and hands.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Ye Gods! At last I shall see a burning city and finish my poem!  45.

dialogues.speaker: FAON
dialogues.text: The flames are swallowing up the people! Rome is dying, Sire! Vinicius walks off down the terrace, not listening to the conversation. He jumps on his horse and rides towards Rom Nero turns to Tigellinus.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Tigellinus. Will I be in time to see the fire? The face of Tigellinus shows great excitement as he savor NeroвЂ™s every word.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: Sire, the show is for you.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 50 NIGHT_EXT_HILLS AROUND ROME
dialogues.text: A horse with its neck outstretched and panting heavily rushes past gardens and hedges. Vinicius leans over the horseвЂ™s neck. He urges the animal on. The horse and Vinicius reach the hill. On the horizon we the city engulfed in gold and pink, with flashes, like distant thunder.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 51 NIGHT_EXT_HILLS AROUND ROME
dialogues.text: The horse on top of the hill rears up on its hind legs. Vinicius calms him down and looks down on the city. The burning city can be seen in the distance, a mass of f and smoke. Vinicius heads down towards the city.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 52 NIGHT_EXT_ROME STREET IN FIRE 1
dialogues.text: Vinicius tries to navigate with his horse through the chaotic crowds in the city. The forms of people are hard see through the thick black smoke. Every now and then a terrified face, black from the smoke flashes into view. Screams of pain, anger, and curses can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: Death to Nero! Mother killer! Down with the tyrant! We know he did this! Assassins! Arsonists! Hang them all!  46.

dialogues.speaker: THE CRISPUS HOUS
dialogues.text: Vinicius enters the street on which Crispus lives. From t entrance of the street fire can be seen. The fire quickly moves towards the rider, engulfing and consuming the vine surrounding him. The horse rears back in fear. A RUNAWAY runs past. Vinicius grabs him by his tunic, alm falling off of his horse.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Where are they!?

dialogues.speaker: RUNAWAY
dialogues.text: ThereвЂ™s no one here! The Christians have left for Ostrianum! He disappears in the smoke. The horse turns around. Its hooves pound on the flagstones of the street as it disappears into the clouds of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 54 NIGHT_EXT_CRISPUS HOUSE_COURTYARD 2 DURING THE F
dialogues.text: Vinicius on horseback enters a Courtyard. There are still tongues of fire on the walls and roof. Vinicius hangs limply over the horseвЂ™s neck. He falls, rolling onto the grass and lies on his back. His face is blackened with smoke. He falls unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: NeroвЂ™s entourage stops at the edge of an aqueduct. Nero takes a few steps forwards and from the top looks down on the burning city. They are surrounded by scorched tree trunks and a growing angry crowd. Nero turns to his entourage and recites a short line with pathetic voice as he gestures towards the burning city.

dialogues.speaker: NERON
dialogues.text: Homeless ruler of a homeless people, where will I lay my miserable head this night... From beneath the aqueduct, the roaring of the crowd grows louder.  47.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 56 NIGHT_EXT_BURNING ROME_AQUEDUCT
dialogues.text: Nero tunes his zither and looks down. Striking the string he begins to sing.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Oh star of my ancestors, dear birthplace ... Oh star of my ancestors, dear birthplace... After these few words, he throws the zither into a gap in the aqueduct where it smashes among the crowd below. Nero wraps himself in his robe and stands in statuesque pose. A sinister howl comes from the crowd down below.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: WhereвЂ™s Caesar!?! He put us in hell! Death to Nero! Mother killer! Down with the tyrant! Nodding his head, Nero says plaintively

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: This is how the people appreciate me and my poetry. Tigellinus comes up beside him.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: Have the praetorian guards called out to attack them, Sire. Petronius comes up on NeroвЂ™s other side.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Speak to your people, Sire and promise them something. Tigellinus glares at Petronius. Nero raises his head to t sky and with a heavy sigh sarcastically comments on the proposal.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Would you have the divine Caesar speak to the rabble? Nero stares at Tigellinus.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: You go down to them! Tigellinus lowers his head in silence.  48.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Caesar, I will go.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Yes, you my most faithful ... Go and lavish promises on them!

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 57 NIGHT_EXT_BURNING ROME_AQUEDUCT
dialogues.text: Petronius alone stands on the edge of the aqueduct, stari at the crowd. He raises his arms and after a while the hubbub subsides.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Petronius! ItвЂ™s Petronius!

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Citizens! From afar, Nero listens to Petronius, adding his own comments to the speech.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: ...And you scum...

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: The city will be rebuilt.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: ...as soon as weвЂ™re done with the show...

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Caesars gardens will be opened to you.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: ...just donвЂ™t throw any garbage around or bring your goats...

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: From tomorrow, grain, wine and oil will be handed out!

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: ...fill your bellies till you choke...

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Then Caesar will organise for you games such as Rome has never seen before.  49.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: and will never see again...

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Great feasts and generous gifts await you!

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: ...Rome has burnt to the ground - long live Rome!

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Bread! Bread! Games! Bread and games!Bread! Bread! Games! Bread and games!

dialogues.speaker: FIRE
dialogues.text: Nazarius leans over Vinicius and splashes the riderвЂ™s f with water. Marcus Vinicius opens his heavy eyelids. The temporarily blinds him.

dialogues.speaker: NAZARIUS
dialogues.text: Our house is burned down, Master! Vinicius tries to pick himself up.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Where is she?!

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 59 DAY_INT_ROME_UNDERGROUND CAVERN
dialogues.text: An underground cavern. A few lights give a faint glow. Th cavern is filled with people kneeling and praying.

dialogues.speaker: NAZARIUS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: There are caves beyond the gardens of Agrippina. They have taken shelter there. Standing against a wall is a more clearly illuminated Pet the Apostle. He makes the sign of the cross with his hand

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Peace be with you! The crowd responds with a murmur of pained and fearful voices.  50.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Do not abandon us! Do not leave us on this day of judgment! Peter raises his hands.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Woe to the world, and woe to the sinful. Fire has come to the city of crime, but the Lord has shown mercy to those of you washed by baptism! Peace be with you! Peter moves among the crowd, blessing them. Suddenly, he stands opposite Vinicius. Vinicius bows his head low. He looks around and sees a vat of water. Someon hands him a twig with a few leaves still swaying on it. Peter dips it into the water and sprays Vinicius with it, baptizing him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I baptize you in the name of the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit. Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 60 DAY_INT_ROME_MODEST COTTAGE HOUSE_CHAMBER
dialogues.text: Interior of a modest cottage on the outskirts of the city Lygia is busy hanging fish on a line. She does not see Vinicius who has entered and is standing, watching his beloved Lygia. When Lygia turns and sees Vinicius, she for a moment does not know what to do. But her feelings overcome her doubt she throws herself into his arms. There is a wooden pigeo sculptured by Nazarius sitting over their heads, on the ledge in the wall.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I promised you that IвЂ™d never leave you...

dialogues.speaker: LYGIA
dialogues.text: And then IвЂ™1l say "where you go Caius, there go I Caia".

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: This very day weвЂ™1l sail for Sicily. My house is your house.  51.

dialogues.speaker: LYGIA
dialogues.text: My heart is your heart. During this time Peter the Apostle has also entered the room. As he sees them in such a love and community, he approaches them and takes ViniciusвЂ™s right hand and joi with LygiaвЂ™s right hand.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Love one another. There is no sin in this love of yours. Vinicius looks into the eyes of Lygia.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I, Marcus Vinicius, take you Lygia Callina for my wife and promise that I will not leave you for as long as I live. Lygia looks into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LIGIA
dialogues.text: So help us, Lord God Almighty. Nazarius runs into the room.

dialogues.speaker: NAZARIUS
dialogues.text: The gladiators have revolted. They are killing everyone! Peter silences him with a gesture and directs his words t Vinicius.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This is a great evil In the distance we hear the growing roars of lions collec in an animal pit.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t stray away, Father. IвЂ™1l come for you. Vinicius straitens Lygia for the last time and runs out o the room. The roars of the lions become increasingly loud and clear There are upcoming screams of people, as well.  52.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: This way! Run! God! Help us! Horror overcomes the faces of those gathered.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did He abandon His flock?

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: SCENE 61 DAY_INT_ROME_PALATINO_NEROвЂ™S CHAMBER

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Palatino. NeroвЂ™s chamber.Petronius stares at Nero.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Sire, you need to go to Hellas. ItвЂ™s getting too dangerous in Rome. Tigellinus abruptly interrupts him.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: That is not a good idea! Civil war could erupt before you get to Ostia, Sire! The Praetorians may betray us! Angry voices from a crowd approaches from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Death to the arsonists of Rome! Mother killer! Coward! Death to the tyrant! Arsonist! Burn him at the stake! Burn them all!

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: They have enough grain and oil, what more do they want?

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: Vengeance. Nero squints and collects his thoughts for a moment. Suddenly an idea comes to mind and he smiles evilly.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: And vengeance requires a victim, Tigellinus. You must go out to them and admit it was you who set fire to Rome.  53. Tigellinus looks petrified. After a moment he looks at NeroвЂ™s with defiance.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: I burned Rome on your orders! Nero and Tigellinus measure each other like wild beasts. The sudden voice of Faon standing in the doorway to the h interrupts the moment.

dialogues.speaker: FAON
dialogues.text: The divine Poppea wishes to see Tigellinus. SCENE 62 DAY_INT_ROME_PALATINO_POPPEAвЂ™S CHAMBER PoppeaвЂ™s Chamber. The Empress lies on a bed holding the collar of a huge leopard. In front of Tigellinus - Chilon

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: So, you say that Vinicius...?

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Yes, Master.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: And how about Petronius?

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Perhaps! It may very well be. Poppea bursts into hysterical laughter.

dialogues.speaker: POPPEA
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t be ridiculous, Tigellinus. Petronius, that lover of life and pleasure - a Christian? You wonвЂ™t protect us with this. The anger of the people will turn against Nero and will fall on me. Chilon falls to his knees and crawls towards Tigellinus, glancing at Poppea the entire time.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Vinicius is with them. I swear! Lygia too is a Christian. They have married. They mean to disappear from sight, and leave Nero in this stench of a burnt city.  54.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: You came here with with? You have nothing on Petronius?! Chilon rubs his fingers together insinuating money. Tigellinus rejects him with a kick.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Catch the nephew in the net, and the uncle will fall into the trap of his own accord. And may I count on your good graces, Master? SCENE 63 DAY_INT_ROME_PALATINO_NEROвЂ™S CHAMBER The room in which Nero resides. Poppea and Tigellinus ent Nero laughs sheepishly, clearly nervous. From afar, under the Palatine, the screams of the crowd can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: The mother killer set fire to Rome! Death to Nero!

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s getting nasty. We had better make our escape to Hellas. Caesar walks over to Tigellinus.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: The people already know that it was Caesar who set fire to Rome!

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: If I so desire, I can turn the people against you.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: I havenвЂ™t killed my mother. They remember Agrippina and havenвЂ™t forgiven you that... crime.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: You played your part in it.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: As in everything that goes on in the palace. Silence.  55. Petronius listens from the side of the room, looking out from a window at the hills covered by the figures of the growing crowd.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Do my ears deceive me, Nero; do you really intend to let this muscle-bound fool have the last word?! Tigellinus looks at Petronius as if he had been struck wi an arrow in the windpipe. All of a sudden he takes a more conciliatory tone.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: The people need revenge and... someone to sacrifice. You have heard, Sire, of the followers of this prophet, Christ? As soon as we agreed to have him hung on the cross, they made a God of him.It was they who set fire to Rome! NeroвЂ™s face begins to assume an expression of anger, gr and indignation.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: What did this poor city do to deserve such a crime ... at their hands? And what is Rome to do now, with these beasts? Poppea walks up to the emperor.

dialogues.speaker: POPPEA
dialogues.text: They are your enemies! Punish the arsonists!

dialogues.speaker: TYGELLINUS
dialogues.text: They go around the city trying to convince people to turn against Caesar. Nero makes another theatrical gesture.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: What punishment and torment fits such a crime? Petronius comes out of the shadows, silently and intently watching the faces of Poppea and Tigellinus and then Nero He starts to talk with a growing power in his voice.  56.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Beware, Sire, for they will say that Nero burned Rome, but threw the blame on the innocent. Nero - the coward. Tigellinus stands by Nero.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: One word from you, and Petronius will forever hold his peace. Nero looks at Petronius, cocking his head, feeling hurt. Petronius

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: Though he has wounded my heart, I still love him like a brother.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: If you treat your brother as you treated your mother, there will soon be nobody in the world to love you. walks out silently.

dialogues.speaker: PALACE_HALL_VIEW THROUGH THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: House of Petronius. PORTERS quickly bring a litter throug the gate. Eunice is Petronius Petronius gets out and heads towards the entrance. there to greet him.

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: Vinicius was waiting for you! He wanted to say goodbye. This very day, he departs with Lygia for Sicily. embraces her affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: And if it should happen that we had to part?

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: Where you go, Master, there I go.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Some voyages have to be taken alone.  57.

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: Take me with you. Petronius strokes her golden hair and with his arm around her they both enter the house. From inside can be heard their voices, interrupted by EuniceвЂ™s laughter, as if they were children playing.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: I have no right to decide about the life of the beautiful Eunice.

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Eunice belongs to you.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Then I am the happiest man in Rome. There are some things that cannot be taken from me.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 65 PETRONIUS PALACE HALL VIEW THROUGH THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: He has barely crossed the threshold of his house, when Petronius must regretfully put an end to EuniceвЂ™s joy.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
