dialogues.text: Forgive me. I do not ask you to accompany me. His face maintains a carefree expression, trying to hide depression. He kisses Eunice on the forehead, turns aroun and disappears into his library.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 66 NIGHT_INT_PETRONIUS PALACE_LIBRARY
dialogues.text: Library. Petronius is writing, leaning over his desk. We his outline from behind, along with the outline of column leading to the garden. After a few moments, Paul the Apostle appears in the entrance. He stands for a moment looking at Petronius.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You do not want her to accompany you and you are setting her free. Note well GodвЂ™s goodness and severity: he was severe with cut branches, and for you he is good - if you persist in this goodness. At the sound of his voice, Petronius looks up, confused.  58.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Who are you? A thief?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: They told me I would find Vinicius here. I say to you, I, Paul, a servant of Christ Jesus, called to be an apostle to preach the good news from God. Petronius snorts and laughs bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: "Enemy of Rome!" "Arsonist"! Are you here seeking revenge?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do not mete out justice yourselves, but leave that to God. "I mete out punishment, and I will repay for everything" - says the Lord. DonвЂ™t be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good. Stunned by the discussion, Petronius stands up and paces room.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Good? What is that compared to wealth, fame and happiness, which the tyrant can destroy at a momentвЂ™s notice?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wish well for those who persecute you. Live in harmony with one another. Do not pretend to love, but really love other people.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Death cancels everything. Have you not heard the groans of victims?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If we believe that Jesus died and rose again, God will take those who have died in Jesus and lead them into eternity.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: If God is on your side, what will become of those who are against you?  59. Petronius lifts his head to hear the reply, but Paul is n longer there.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 67 AFTERNOON_EXT_ROME_STREET VIEW_FORUM ROMANUM
dialogues.text: Street of Rome. Crowd. You can hear the roar and drunken singing of the crowd among the ruins of the still smoking city.

dialogues.speaker: CROWDS
dialogues.text: Christians to the lions! They poison our wells! Let the animals at them! Get rid of these fanatics! Death to all Christians! Death to all Christians! The litter with Vinicius is having trouble moving through the crowd. After a while it disappears into the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 69 DAY_INT_PETRONIUS PALACE_LIBRARY
dialogues.text: Petronius stands with his back to the library table, exac where Paul stood before. Standing in the dark corner, he looks out the window at the vegetation growing around the columns of the atrium. He doesnвЂ™t turn round at the sound of Vinicius approach

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Caesar has accused the Christians of setting fire to Rome! Vinicius, angry, runs into the library.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Have you hidden her?

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: They sent over a hundred Praetorians after them. They took everyone away. The elderly, women and children. Did you know about this?

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: LetвЂ™s say that I underestimated Tigellinus. What about Lygia?

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Apparently sheвЂ™s together with the others in prison.  60. Petronius claps his hands. Out of nowhere his female servants appear.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Bring swords and mantles. Finally Petronius turns around, but his face is still hid in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: YouвЂ™1l1 have to bribe the guards to release her immediately. Otherwise it will be too late!

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Talk to Caesar. Nero loves you. He will release her for you.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Do you think a man who sentenced his own mother to death can love? Today, IвЂ™m the first he would deprive of a voice and the last person heвЂ™d like to hear.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 70 DAY_EXT_ROME_PRISON GATE
dialogues.text: Dressed in mantles, Petronius and Vinicius approach the prison walls. As they get closer they see a double line o soldiers surrounding the sealed entrance to the prison.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Arsonits! They burned down Rome! Death to Christians! Let the animals at them! Get rid of these fanatics! Death to Christians! Throw them to the lions! LetвЂ™s rid the city of these fanatics! Death to all Christians! LetвЂ™s see their God save them now! Petronius searches for the commander, eventually spots hi and approaches him. It is KRICSOS.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Hail, Kricsos! You have been ordered to guard the jail? Kricsos stands at attention.  61.

dialogues.speaker: KRICSOS
dialogues.text: Yes, noble Petronius. The Prefect fears there may be an attempt to free the arsonists.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: My slave is in there. This is some mistake. I know her well and I know that she had nothing to do with them.

dialogues.speaker: KRICSOS
dialogues.text: My orders are to let no one out! Despite this, Petronius takes a step forward, Niger block his path.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t you dare.... You can hear the clinking of weapons from the PRAETORIAN GUARDS.

dialogues.speaker: KRICSOS
dialogues.text: That means no one, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: And are you also forbidden to let anyone in?

dialogues.speaker: KRICSOS
dialogues.text: ....That was not prohibited.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: So tell your men to let me through the cordon. I want to find those who burned down my house. After a few moments of debating this in his head, Kricsos gives his men the signal to let them in. Vinicius turns round, embraces Petronius, says goodbye an enters the prison.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 71 DAY_INT_ROME_PRISON
dialogues.text: Vinicius passes over the threshold of the prison and is enveloped in darkness. The hallways and cells are filled with people. They stand calmly, quietly, most of them are praying. Words of prayer reverberate throughout the priso  62.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Our Father who art in heaven, hallowed be thy name. Thy kingdom come.Thy will be doneon earth as it is in heaven.Give us this day our daily bread, and forgive us our trespasses,as we forgive those who trespass against us,and lead us not into temptation,but deliver us from evil. In the meantime, Vinicius wanders around helplessly, look for Lygia. A CENTURION approaches Vinicius; he leans over and whispers in his hear.

dialogues.speaker: CENTURION
dialogues.text: IвЂ™ve seen you before, Sir. In Ostrianum.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Are you....? With his long Gallic sword the centurion draws a fish in sand.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I must find Lygia.

dialogues.speaker: CENTURION
dialogues.text: SheвЂ™s no longer here. Vinicius grabs him by the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Do you know where she is now? The centurion shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Well, do you know how to get out of here? Centurion turns around, nods his head towards Vinicius an disappears into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 72 DAY_EXT_ROME_PRISON EXIT_STREET
dialogues.text: Vinicius exits through a side door from the darkness of t prison and comes out into afternoon sunlight.  63. He takes a few steps and encounters the Apostle Paul. He sees him, however, from a distance across the entire widt of the street. The Apostle looks in ViniciusвЂ™s face. A litter passes between Paul and Vinicius. The voices of its PORTERS can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERS
dialogues.text: Make way for the noble Chilo! Make way! Vinicius grabs the edge of the litter and tips it in his direction. Chilon slides across to him, his eyes wide wit surprise.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Greetings to you, Chilo. Chilon tries to cover his face with his arm.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Hail, Vinicius, but do not hold me up. I hasten to my friend Tigellinus! Vinicius grabs him by the robe and screams.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: It was you who betrayed them! Chilon replies arrogantly.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: My friend, if you have a request, come to my house. I welcome all visitors and clients in the morning, after I have taken my bath. Vinicius is still half holding on to his tunic. SLOW MOTION. Some invisible force pulls Vinicius back. He looks back and meets the eyes of Paul. In one flash of tr there is an explosion of energy and agreement between the two men. Vinicius turns his head back on Chilon and looks deeply i his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: May God forgive you. Vinicius then finally lets go of his tunic and lets the litter pass on.  64. Vinicius then looks back to where Paul was standing, but is already gone.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 73 DAY_EXT_APPIAN ROAD
dialogues.text: Appian Road is empty at this time of a day. There is only long shadow of PETER THE APOSTLE, who looks ahead at the hilly surrounding area. Beneath his hood you can see his grave expression and tired face. The sun begins to appear from over the hillsides. Peter shields his eyes with his hand, trying to see the white pigeon, which flapped its wings loudly. Peter sinks to his knees, resting his hands and head on h staff. Around his outline appears a pulsing, golden light Than the single beam of light splits like a prism into tw streaks - one of them is pale pink - another clear luminous. The staff slides from under him and he falls face down in the Sand, his head still covered by his hood. Peter stretches his hands forward as if reaching for someoneвЂ™ feet. Silence falls. The golden light fades. Peter raises his h slightly.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Quo Vadis, Domine?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: If you abandon my people, I shall go to Rome to be crucified once again.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Christ! Forgive me! Suddenly, there is Nazarius coming from the distance. He pulls the bridle of a gray Donkey. The Donkey denies to g with four hooves. Each step is difficult for them. Nazarius managed to pull up the Donkey. The confused face of Nazarius as he bends down over the o man. Then from above them a pained voice speaks out. The golden light fades as Nazarius grabs Peter and helps up off his knees.  65.

dialogues.speaker: NAZARIUS
dialogues.text: Let us not delay, Peter, at any time they may catch up with us here. The Apostle Peter gets up, and leaning on his cane turns around to stare in the direction of Rome. Suddenly he hea back towards the city. Nazarius catches up to him and gra his arm, trying to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: NAZARIUS
dialogues.text: Where are you going, Master? Peter slowly turns his head, holding his staff in one han and pointing towards the city with the other.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: To Rome! In the distance you can see the Circus.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 74 DAY_EXT_ROME_CIRCUS
dialogues.text: The Arena of the big Circus. View from the imperial terra towards the audience. Nero sits on an elevated podium with the magnificently dressed Poppea beside him. They are surrounded by the cou Petronius is sitting next to Tigellinus. Chilon is on the right hand side. The place to the left of Petronius is empty. Petronius looks around. Vinicius takes a seat next to his uncle.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Have you found her? Vinicius shakes his head. Nero looks towards Petronius and Vinicius. He gets up. The crowd in the Circus roars and cheers.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Nero! Nero! Divine Augustus! Christians to the lions!  66.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 75 DAY_EXT_ROME_CIRCUS
dialogues.text: Arena. Massive gates are located on the left and right si of the arena. The shrill sound of trumpets breaks the silence. As soon as the trumpets fall silent, the gate on the righ side opens with a crash. From the black depths of the ope gate emerge human figures that slowly move towards the center of the arena. The crowd in the Circus murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Christians! Christians! Christians! The Christians huddle together in the middle of the arena squinting under the sun. They kneel and bow their heads together while holding each other.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Bring on the animals! The animals! The trumpets begin to play again. The gate on the left si of the Circus opens. From a black tunnel emerges a lion. Behind it, more lions rush out. The animals sniff the air, growl and squint in the bright light. The crowd Howls with delight. From the middle of the cluster of Christians comes the so -"Christus Regnat".

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 76 DAY_EXT_ROME_CIRCUS
dialogues.text: The scene is accompanied by music. Images shown from a distance, without dramatic shots. NeroвЂ™s terrace. With his sapphire monocle, Caesar looks on the arena. PoppeaвЂ™s eyes shine with excitement. She embraces her husbandвЂ™s neck and shoulders. Tigellinus wears an expression of contempt and triumph. A lion lurks closer, readying to pounce on the tight clus of kneeling people. He pounces and seizes in its mouth th neck of an old man. The crowd goes wild. Increasingly horrified by this sight, Chilon slides lower and lower into his seat. The lions drag their victims across the sand, the arena i now filled with the screams of those being murdered.  67.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 77 DAY_EXT_ROME_CIRCUS
dialogues.text: ChilonвЂ™s head is tilted back unnaturally. Face pale, ey closed, sweaty forehead. With a wild roar of laughter Tigellinus jerks ChilonвЂ™s arm.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: Look! Look! This is your doing! Petronius from behind Tigellinus reaches out towards Chil With his carved cane he taps lightly on his pulsating Ada apple.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: The gods created him a foul villain. He has become a veritable demon! But even a demon cannot endure this. Chilon wheezes, his eyes shut tight. He reaches breaking point.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: Enough, Caesar! Enough! Vinicius looks up. He sees something and nudges Petronius arm. Petronius follows his gaze. At the top of the arena stands Peter, making the sign of the cross with his hand. Standing in the light, he looks like a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Look! Peter is here! PeterвЂ™s piercing eyes are looking straight at Petronius Instead of Peter, all he can see is s pigeon in an oncomi white pigeon.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: I canвЂ™t see anyone. PeterвЂ™s piercing eyes are looking straight at Petronius even though he denies his existence. Suddenly, a big whit pigeon is appearing, where Peter was supposed to stand. Some strange energy passes between them. The howling of t crowd in the Circus mixes with the roars of the maddened animals. Tigellinus leans into NeroвЂ™s ear.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: I have something even better arranged for tomorrow.  68.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 78 TWILIGHT_EXT_ROME_PALATINO GARDENS
dialogues.text: Twilight. Palatine Gardens. The area where cypress trees once grew is now covered with large crosses. On these are tied half naked people, their arms attached to the crosse by thick ropes, their heads hanging down, their bodies covered in bruises and marks from beatings. The crosses are draped in dry garlands of ivy. Suddenly a large peal of trumpets. Nero looks down on the scene from the windows of the Palatine. He makes a gesture and puts his monocle to his to examine the nearest cross. On it hangs Crispus. Standing next to Nero is the pale Chilon, swaying on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 79 TWILIGHT_EXT_ROME_PALATINO GARDENS
dialogues.text: Darkness falls. Close-up of the crucified Crispus. His he slowly rises. The victim is still alive. He opens his eyes and stares a Chilon. His chapped lips move silently, his chest rising with each breath as his face shines. He whispers.

dialogues.speaker: CRISPUS
dialogues.text: I forgive and ask for forgiveness.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: Set the fire. The ivy is immediately lit, lighting up the main avenue o the garden as the flames travel up the shafts of the crosses. ChilonвЂ™s white robe shines yellow and purple in the reflection of the fires. He hides his face in his hands a is shaken by spasms.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 80 TWILIGHT_EXT_ROME_PALATINO GARDENS
dialogues.text: Chilon runs down the middle of the avenue past the burnin crosses, the flames whipping at him as he tries to find a exit from the garden. Once past the fires, he trips and falls, crashing to the ground.  69.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 81 TWILIGHT_EXT_ROME_PALATINE GARDENS
dialogues.text: A hooded figure bends over Chilon and touches his arm. Chilon fears to open his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: I am cursed, damned. The face of Paul emerges from under the hood.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I bring you salvation.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: For me there can be no salvation. Paul then draws a cross on his forehead. From ChilonвЂ™s comes a moan.

dialogues.speaker: CHILO
dialogues.text: Christ! The Apostle Paul disappears back into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 82 TWIGLIHT_EXT_ROME_PALATINE GARDENS
dialogues.text: Trumpets, noise and fanfare. Suddenly out of the darkness emerges a figure wearing a s covered robe. He stands in front of the imperial retinue. is Chilon. He points at Nero.

dialogues.speaker: CHILO
dialogues.text: Murderer of your own mother! Woe to you! It was you who set fire to Rome. And Rome will have its vengeance on you. Your time has passed. He points dramatically at the burning crosses.

dialogues.speaker: CHILON
dialogues.text: I swear that the innocent are being killed here. The arsonist of Rome is this one! This man! With his right hand Chilon points at Nero and freezes in that pose. Silence falls. At first single voices are hear then a growing number of ominous cries rise up from the crowd.  70.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Arsonist! Murderer! Tyrant! Mother Killer! Despot! Redbeard! Down with Caesar! Down with tyranny!

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 83 TWIGLIGHT_EXT_ROME_PALATINE GARDENS
dialogues.text: A still burning stake collapses in front of the caravan o horses, scaring them and knocking Chilon to the ground. H head and neck are showered with sparks and burning splinters. The frightened horses panic and stampede, trampling Chilon. Wheels run over his limp body.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: SCENE 84-85 DAY_INT_ROME_PALATINO_NEROвЂ™S CHAMBER

dialogues.speaker: VOICES, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Arsonist! Murderer! Tyrant! Mother Killer! Nero the murderous dog! Who set our city on fire?! You burnt my house, you dog! We will have vengeance! Chamber in Pallatino - the palace of the emperor. Nero is walking around the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: The ship is waiting in Naples, Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: So we shall take a vacation on Hellas after all? Petronius stands before Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Before you sail Sire, and deprive us of your divine presence, do faithful Petronius one last favour.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™s that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Bless the young couple.  71.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: YouвЂ™re getting married?

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: Vinicius wants to marry the Lygian hostage.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: Nero, sheвЂ™s one of them. SheвЂ™s in the prison.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: She found herself there through your stupidity, Tigellinus. TigellinusвЂ™s face turns black with anger. Nero squints suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: One thing that worries me, Petronius, is that you take sides with the arsonists. Now Nero looks at Tigellinus.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: We will organise a wedding the likes of which Rome has never seen.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 86 TWILIGHT_EXT_ROME_PETRONIUS PALACE_COLLONADE
dialogues.text: Twilight. In front of PetroniusвЂ™s home. The sky is cove in driving clouds. Fires lit in the house cast long shado along the walls. Leaning against the columns of the house is Vinicius, waiting for word from Petronius. At the sight of his chariot, he jumps up and waits at the front for it to sto

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Tell me that you bring her freedom! Petronius does not reply right away. Then from the darkne appears a figure in a gray tunic. HeвЂ™s obviously in hid He looks around nervously, making sure he isnвЂ™t being followed. He whispers.

dialogues.speaker: NAZARIUS
dialogues.text: Is that you, noble Vinicius?  72.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: Nazarius? Where did you come from?

dialogues.speaker: NAZARIUS
dialogues.text: I have a message from Lygia. In her fever she keeps repeating your name. Ursus is with her.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: How do you know this?

dialogues.speaker: NAZARIUS
dialogues.text: I know a centurion.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m going with you! Nazarius begins to run off in panic. He stops, turns, and from a distance conveys the most important part of his message.

dialogues.speaker: NAZARIUS
dialogues.text: Lygia asks you, Master, to persevere in your love and trust of God. Nazarius raises his eyes towards heaven. The moonlight filters directly onto his face. Suddenly the heavens open with lightning and thunder. The sudden downpour soaks the Nazarius disappears in the pouring rain and darkness. Vinicius cries out to him, but the rain drowns out his words.

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: I will wait for her! Always! Petronius wraps his arm around Vinicius and forcefully brings him inside.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Pull yourself together, soldier. Or pray, if you know how.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 87 DAY_EXT_ROME_CIRCUS
dialogues.text: Circus. Brilliant sunlight. Nero is on the terrace. With is Tigellinus, Poppea, and even Hasto, Pitagoras and Faon The sand in the arena has turned to pools of mud from the rain.  73. Petronius sits away from Nero, in an adjacent terrace, ne to Vinicius, who is as white as a sheet. With dark rings under his eyes, he stares at the gates. Behind them armed PRAETORIANS hold prisoners. AS always, a peal of trumpets marks the beginning of the spectacle. Nero is curious how the spectacle is affecting Petronius and his nephew. He canвЂ™t resist staring at th through his monocle. Suddenly he bursts out laughing and shouts to Tigellinus, who is leaning on NeroвЂ™s chair.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: I underestimated you, Tigellinus. YouвЂ™re worse than me.

dialogues.speaker: TIGELLINUS
dialogues.text: I had lessons from the best master Nero.

dialogues.speaker: NERO
dialogues.text: I can do anything, but youвЂ™ve managed to amaze Petronius himself. Look! Petronius looks pale and exhausted. He slowly stands up. he can be seen standing tall above the others, staring at one point in the arena. He slowly turns his head and look straight at Nero. Very slowly and clearly he speaks over noise of the trumpets.

dialogues.speaker: PETRONIUS
dialogues.text: If their God really exists, what will become of those who are against Him? The gate on the right opens, revealing the dark abyss of tunnel. A moment later a huge athletic figure emerges. Ursus ente the arena. Struck almost blind by the rays of the sun, he squints and looks around. He is half naked and devoid of weapon. He kneels down and bows his head as if in prayer. freezes in that position. The crowd begins to murmur, the scream.  74.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 88 DAY_EXT_ROME_CIRCUS
dialogues.text: The left gate opens and an enormous German bull runs out. has a half naked girl tied to its back. With chapped lips pale Vinicius whispers

dialogues.speaker: VINICIUS
dialogues.text: God, I trust in you. He closes his eyes and mouths a silent prayer. Ursus sees Lygia hanging limply across the bullвЂ™s back. charges towards the bull and extends his hands.

dialogues.speaker: URSUS
dialogues.text: (savage war cry) Ruuaaaaah! The bull rears its powerful head, its horns ripping Ursus left side. Blood pours from the wound.

dialogues.speaker: URSUS
dialogues.text: (a warriorsвЂ™ shout of pain) Urraah! Ursus falls to the ground as the crowd roars and the bull runs around the arena.

dialogues.speaker: CROWDS
dialogues.text: Get him! Get him! Kill the giant! Bleed him like a bull! The injured Ursus struggles to get up. He sizes up the be and then lunges at it, grabbing it by the horns.

dialogues.speaker: URSUS
dialogues.text: (warriorвЂ™s savage grunt and cry) Uuurrrrrrrah! The bull starts shaking its head. Ursus tightens his muscles around the bullвЂ™s neck. The animal pushes back. Ursus plants his feet in the ground, halting the beastвЂ™s advance and they remain momentarily frozen. A murmur of admiration rises from the crowd. Ursus begins to twist the bulls head. Straining his muscl to their limit, he throws the beast to the ground. The animalвЂ™s head, held in the giantвЂ™s vise-like grip, be tilt downward. The beast lets out a roar as it begins to foam at the mouth.  75. A moment later, Ursus twists the bullвЂ™s head into an unnatural position. Roaring, it falls to the sand, kickin with its hooves. Ursus kneels over the fallen beast, take hold of Lygia and lifts her up. The arena goes crazy.

dialogues.speaker: CROWDS
dialogues.text: Giant! Giant! Giant! Giant! Ursus holds her body up as he moves towards the imperial terrace. The air is filled with the sound of thousands of screamin spectators. Ursus kneels, holding up Lygia, extending her towards Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: CROWDS
dialogues.text: Giant! Giant! Giant! Giant!

dialogues.speaker: SCENE 89 DAY_EXT_ROME_CIRCUS
dialogues.text: Imperial terrace. Nero looks down, squinting. Clearly ups he throws down his monocle. He looks around. The crowd chants.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (OFF)
dialogues.text: If I speak in the tongues of men or of angels, but do not have love, I am only a resounding gong or a clanging cymbal. If I have the gift of prophecy and can fathom all mysteries and all knowledge, and if I have a faith that can move mountains, but do not have love, I am nothing. If I give all I possess to the poor and give over my body to hardship that I may boast,but do not have love, I gain nothing. Love is patient, love is kind. It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud. It does not dishonor others, it is not self-seeking, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs. Love does not delight in evil but rejoices with the truth. It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres. Thus faith, hope and love - these three endure: but the greatest of these is love.
